intro: Trimorpha caespitans, commonly known as the tufted broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nourishment. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its dense, grass-like foliage and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid regions, often forming dense clusters on its host. It has a fibrous root system that attaches to the roots of its host, enabling it to absorb nutrients. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the growth and health of its host plants.
